etymologies: Middle English: probably a phonetic development of the Old English feminine personal pronoun hēo, hīe

notes.text: The use of the pronoun he to refer to a person of unspecified sex, once quite acceptable, has become problematic in recent years and is now usually regarded as old-fashioned or sexist. One of the responses to this has been to use she in the way that he has been used, as in only include your child if you know she won't distract you. In some types of writing, such as books on child care or child psychology, use of she has become quite common. In most contexts, however, it is likely to be distracting in the same way that he now is, and alternatives such as he or she or they are preferable. In some contexts where alternation would not distract, writers seeking ‘balanced representation’ vary the gender of the personal pronoun by using she or her in one paragraph, and he or him in the next, and so on. This method should be used with restraint, however, as it may confuse or annoy the reader

definitions: used to refer to a woman, girl, or female animal previously mentioned or easily identified

examples.text: my sister told me that she was not happy

shortDefinitions: used to refer to woman, girl, or female animal

definitions: used to refer to a ship, vehicle, country, or other inanimate thing regarded as female

examples.text: I was aboard the St. Roch shortly before she sailed for the Northwest Passage

shortDefinitions: used to refer to ship, vehicle, country, or other inanimate thing regarded as female

definitions: used to refer to a person or animal of unspecified sex

examples.text: only include your child if you know she won't distract you

shortDefinitions: used to refer to person or animal of unspecified sex

examples.text: she who rocks the cradle rules the world

examples.text: is that a he or a she?
